frameDefinitions: Some Possessor, either a nation, institution, or private individual, controls a Force whose primary functions to defend the Possessor (or, in the case of an institution or individual, some area of land significant to them) and to carry out offensive actions for the Possessor.
After having worked separately for some time, two or more organizational or individual Members are now organized in an Alliance so that they may better pursue some common Purposes.
A Protagonist is sensitive to a Trigger, which has the potential to cause some kind of reaction in the Protagonist.  '' 'Mr. Clinton and his wife Hillary are allergic to cats.'
These words refer to Parts merging to form a Whole.
This frame contains words that describe a set of individuals which possess some Commonality, generally a common attribute.
This frame contains nouns denoting Aggregates of Individuals.
frameExamples: Mr. Clinton and his wife Hillary are <t>allergic</t> to cats.
The two droplets <t>merge</t>, and then travel down the windowpane even faster.
An <t><fex name='Agg'>army</fex></t> of postal workers descended on my office.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Force</fen> is the body of soldiers that acts in military capacity for the <fen>Possessor</fen>. This role is incorporated in each word in this frame.
The <fen>Possessor</fen> is the nation, institution, or individual who possesses and/or controls the <fen>Force</fen>.
The entity of which the individuals are <fen>Members</fen>.
The persons or groups belonging to the <fen>Alliance</fen>.
That group or individual which has joined the <fen>Alliance</fen> which is grammatically more prominent when the <fen>Members</fen> are presented separately.
That group or individual which has joined the <fen>Alliance</fen> which is grammatically less  prominent when the <fen>Members</fen> are presented separately.
The <fen>Protagonist</fen> occurs as the External Argument of the targets in this frame. The <fen>Protagonist</fen> represents the one exhibiting the response to the <fen>Trigger</fen>.

The <fen>Trigger</fen> most commonly occurs in a PP Complement headed by <ment>to</ment>. The <fen>Trigger</fen> is that substance or element which causes a health response in the <fen>Protagonist</fen>.
The entities that merge to form a single <fen>Whole</fen>.
The single, undifferentiated entity that is the result of the amalgamation.
The prominent entity that combines with <fen>Part_2</fen> to form a <fen>Whole</fen>.
The less focussed-upon entity that the <fen>Part_1</fen> merges with.
The time at which the <fen>Parts</fen> become amalgamated into a <fen>Whole</fen>
The location at which the amalgamation occurs.

This role denotes the people in possession of the Commonality. This role is usually genetive, the object of a postnominal PP, or null instantiated (INI), and null instantiaton often implies the public at large, as in 'the common good'.
This role denotes an object or attribute which is jointly posessed by the <fen>Entities</fen>.
One of the possesors of the <fen>Commonality</fen>. Can be singular or plural.
One of the possesors of the <fen>Commonality</fen>. Can be singular or plural.
This role identifies the people or things that form  the <fen>Aggregate</fen>.
This role identifies the collection of entities that are the <fen>Aggregate</fen>.
listRoleExamples: The American invasion, which drew 26000 American troops against <fex>General Noriega's</fex> army, was the largest US military operation since Vietnam.
<fex>Our</fex> alliance with Japan is the cornerstone of Asia-Pacific security strategy.
Thanks in part to their coalition <fex>with McCoy</fex>, but thanks also to their seniority and the knowledge of some of their leaders, they hold considerable influence
<fex>Pat's</fex> allergy to dairy products is severe.
Some people are very sensitive <fex>to chemicals in the environment</fex>.
They had all just merged <fex>into one big file</fex>.
<fex>The single smaller soul</fex> merges with the Ur-soul.
The single smaller soul merges <fex>with the Ur-soul</fex>.
Their shared <fex>parents</fex> were their only similarity.
A crowd <fex>of hoodlums</fex> filled the plaza.
A <fex><t>crowd</t></fex> of hoodlums filled the plaza.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: the Center for Climate Change Communication
the Yale Program on Climate Change Communication
A decade and a half later
